paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: The paper investigates whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse Efficacy (Combination)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice receiving the intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combination therapy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human Retrospective Cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, stratified by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human Vaccinated Subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the human retrospective cohort that had received prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse Controls
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice used as controls (vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle) for efficacy experiments.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
